item.title: [BOOK] Seven Languages in Seven Weeks
item.dc:creator: @Imperative Imperative
item.description:
@Imperative wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:17, topic:396531”]i like how you conveniently didnt use the quicksort on the same page

[quote]def qsort: List[Int] => List[Int] = {
case Nil => Nil
case pivot :: tail =>
val (smaller, rest) = tail.partition(_ < pivot)
qsort(smaller) ::: pivot :: qsort(rest)
}[/quote][/quote]

Read full topic

[quote]def qsort: List[Int] => List[Int] = {
case Nil => Nil
case pivot :: tail =>
val (smaller, rest) = tail.partition(_ < pivot)
qsort(smaller) ::: pivot :: qsort(rest)
}[/quote][/quote]Which looks nothing like Java, but I guess you contrive some similarities.

item.title: [BOOK] Seven Languages in Seven Weeks
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

i like how you conveniently didnt use the quicksort on the same page

def qsort: List[Int] => List[Int] = { case Nil => Nil case pivot :: tail => val (smaller, rest) = tail.partition(_ < pivot) qsort(smaller) ::: pivot :: qsort(rest) }

Read full topic

item.title: [BOOK] Seven Languages in Seven Weeks
item.dc:creator: @Imperative Imperative
item.description:
@Imperative wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:15, topic:396531”][quote author=Imperative link=topic=493704.msg3612351#msg3612351 date=1306696208]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=493704.msg3612334#msg3612334 date=1306694709]

like Scala is just a variation of Java so it’d be super easy to learn.

I don’t think you could be more wrong.

In the sense of the simplicity of learning it or that it’s not a variation of Java?
[/quote]The latter

Hello world in Scala:

object HelloWorld { def main(args: Array[String]) { println("Hello, world!") } }

And this is how you compile it.

Scalac helloworld.scala
scala helloworld

Really, it’s compiling like java except some words are changed.
[/quote]So like a billion other languages. The only thing it has in common with Java is that it runs on the JVM.[/quote]
Guess you’re right, then

Read full topic

item.title: [BOOK] Seven Languages in Seven Weeks
item.dc:creator: @Imperative Imperative
item.description:
@Imperative wrote:

Have any of these programming languages even been used for anything? (Aside from Ruby)
All I know about Clojure is that it’s a Lisp dialect targeting the JVM and CLR, and that Scala is only used by Twitter for their backend, but other than that, no idea what software uses those other languages.

Read full topic

item.title: [BOOK] Seven Languages in Seven Weeks
item.dc:creator: @Wyrmcabbage Wyrmcabbage
item.description:
@Wyrmcabbage wrote:

[quote=“Phillipé, post:7, topic:396531”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=493704.msg3611024#msg3611024 date=1306592136]

Pretty bad choice of languages. Especially ruby.

yeah because a language that inherently promotes metaprogramming, is one of the most popular examples of a duck typed language, is one of the more popular (and probably THE most real-world usable) examples of a message passing language and is used super often to write custom DSLs is a really bad language to pick in a book that is all about learning interesting language features

what languages would you choose that aren’t on there, lothy, out of curiosity?
[/quote]

ruby fucking sucks sdfu noob[/quote]

lol’d
And by the way, I wouldn’t mind learning a few of those, like Scala is just a variation of Java so it’d be super easy to learn.

Read full topic
